comments.commentBody: Sarah, Help me!  Say something!
I mean, they would like to see something, and of course, I remember you.  But I've gone public here.  Please get me out of this!

Mr. Franke,

Surely you are aware that some people argue that an accurate reading of section 1 article 8 requires treating the power to provide for the general welfare as merely a preface and not an actual enumerated power provided. They maintain that the broader definition is unconstitutional and that Medicare and Medicaid are actually unconstitutional.

The expansion of the Medicaid program is going to be funded by the federal gov't. Somehow you claim to be OK with the federal gov't spending tax money forked over by citizens any way they see fit as long as the states aren't involved at all, but if they give the states the money to administer the programs for their citizens with guidelines to follow, they are exceeding their constitutional authority.

Even if I take you at your word, I do not understand how you consider your fears to be reasonable, and mine to be imagined. Are there any Democratic Presidential candidates arguing we need to force people to buy broccoli? How big a problem is the requirement to buy life insurance amongst the worlds most tyranical dictatorships? Even countries who were part of the Soviet Union seem to appreciate universal insurance, and I'm sure they would scratch their heads if anyone told them that a requirement to buy insurance was a slide into tyranny.

The questions the judges asked went far beyond the constitutionality of a mandate.
Just hello, lets talk.  Yes, I saw you at the state fare a few years back...

Your husband would notice. I get it. Lets go on. We'll forget this.

But just a Hi. should be ok shouldn't it? On the blog?

I'll keep posting until a friend steps up and posts in response. George, Guy?

You must respond...

"But Groupon has suffered a number of missteps in the harsh glare of scrutiny . . . "

Frankly, no misstep has been quite so profound as failing to offer products that consumers are particularly interested in. There was a time when I was tempted to purchase Groupon's offerings three or four times a week. That all seems to have changed in the months since it went public. Months could go buy with nary an interesting deal out there. Finally, yesterday, I unsubscribed. I suspect that there are hundreds - perhaps thousands - of other consumers out there who are feeling underwhelmed by this once-intriguing company.
Here comes the boom.

I don't get why the author states that continental service is slow. I hate going to cafes in the US after living for years in Portugal, because here the staff whether in chain or local stores only take one customer's order at the time, and you pay right away, while everyone else waits in one line before you. In Portugal, there are long counters, where staff take several orders simultaneously, memorize them, and charge you when you leave. Besides the FAR superior coffee and pastries, the service is light years faster. I suspect the same is the case in other cafe cultures of at least Southern Europe.

Another gripe is the now very played out tendency to have grimy Salvation Army upholstered couches as cafe furniture. I don't want to sit on a porous surface where too many others have. Give me a table and un-upholstered chair any day of the week.

Of course the converse is true, too. A law can be ineffective or somehow "bad" and still be constitutional. It seems to me that a lot of the opposition to the ACA stems from an opinion that it's bad, and that all the constitutional hand-wringing is just a post-facto justification for achieving the political end envisioned: To kill a law that some people don't like. The risk that the Roberts Court faces is the temptation of allowing its ideological preferences to override its nominally neutral adherence to constitutional precedent -- to the detriment of the Court's reputation and, eventually, to the detriment of the nation as a whole.

The right way to strike the ACA, if that's your goal, is to win elections and undo it legislatively. The constitutional attitudes espoused by opponents are, to be kind, novel.

Not that I just want to argue but I do think the availability of an Ethernet port is an important consideration. Although wireless network access is becoming much more mainstream it is not ubiquitous. Our corporate network for example is very limited wireless access. If I were to get an ultra-book for work purposes (and get rid if my HP luggable!!!) I would require a wired network connection. Either that or use wi-fi Internet to get out and VPN back into our corporate environment. However if the ultra-book form factor is strictly an 'on the road' maching then an Ehternet port would be little used.

Good review of the overall market for this type of PC.

But I'm not sure it was worth the space to mention the presence or lack of an ethernet port. I have to imagine the vast majority of people using this type of PC would rarely, if ever, use an ethernet port.

You may be on to something...

I'm not sure that a loan officer's check creates money since, as you say, "Eventually they have to balance this via a combination of deposits and debt..."

But the concept of collateral appraisal is interesting. You lend me $100K and I buy a house with it. 2 weeks later, you re-appraise the house at $1M and lend me an additional $900K. You didn't create more money from the bank - it can only draw from its funds - but you created speculative "money" from my house by re-valuing it.

I bought a boat with my $900K.

2 weeks after this, a professional appraiser values my house at $500K and registers that appraisal with the local tax authority. I lost $500K in house value (but I still have a really cool boat). The Bank, though, still shows the value of my house at your appraisal value of $1M. So the equity you created is still there until I sail to the Cayman Islands.

A bank loans money out of it's liquid assets, constrained by it's capital to debt ratio. If, at the end of the day, it finds itself short on liquidity, it may then borrow over night in the fed funds market (from banks that have excess liquidity) to balance its balance sheet.
They don't, as units, "create money out of thin air"
Collateral is just one component considered when making a loan decision (and hopefully not the primary consideration). It has nothing to do with money creation.

comments.userDisplayName: On the receiving end of the nonsense
comments.commentBody:
You need to think about the balance sheet of the bank. How do I draw down this loan created out of thin air, if the bank does not have liquid asset to make the payment on my behalf, or provide me with cash to do so?

And if the bank creates a loan out of nothing, what appears on the other side of the balance sheet? The loan officer might not need to check, but there sure is some funding (deposits or something else) on the liabilities side of the bank's balance sheet.

This isn't even economics, it's basic bookkeeping.

I have worked in bank lending. Bank loan officers can in fact write checks out of thin air based on collateral appraisal. Eventually they have to balance this via a combination of deposits and debt, but they are different from other financial intermediaries in having the privilege of issuing credit (fungible with currency) at will.

The kicker is they can buy each others' debt using the same thin air money creation, which has fueled the exponential growth of debt over the decades.

This is distinct from the fractional reserve banking story. I suggest you do some research and you will find that banks every day create credit out of nothing but collateral appraisals.

Brown v. Board of Education was unpopular too, but the Justices are appointed because, they are, or should be, more enlightened than the rest of us. After Brown was decided, Arkansas Governor Faubus called out his state's National Guard to block black students' entry to high school, causing President Eisenhower to federalize Arkansas national guard. Governor Wallace of Alabama infamously blocked the door the to University of Alabama to block two black students from attending.

Equal access to health care should be as much as right as equal access to education.

The law is flawed, but it is as good as a start as we are going to get in this congressional climate.

I lost faith in this Court after Bush v. Gore, so I am not particularly optimistic about the outcome. As a result, I was not surprise at the outcome to Citizen United.

However, the health care law is less overtly political and millions of citizens are already benefiting, so I it is my hope the Court does not strike down the entire law.
Correction, Democratic Presidents nominate moderate judges, while republican presidents nominate extrem right wing partisan hacks.

Brown v. Board was also a UNANIMOUS decision... one that was very hard-won, but it was understood that a decision so momentous, and so contrary to the entire American experience to that point HAD to be either unanimous, or not at all. There could be left no doubt in anyone's mind, nor any defense in court, that "separate but equal" was at its end (well, at least in so far as any government involvement was concerned).

The court, since Bush v. Gore, has been more than willing to do away with decades and centuries of law on 5-4 decisions that are hotly contested. No added weight is given to the wisdom of jurists who went before, no deference or humility exists.

Interesting analysis. I think the argument that the Court has become political (especially in close, controversial cases like the health care law) is largely true. It's not an accident that the justices Barack Obama nominated look like they would vote to uphold the health care law, while those nominated by George W. Bush look likely to vote to strike it down. I'm not sure there's anything entirely "wrong" with this. If you're a conservative, you're going to agree with the conservative position on the judicial system, which tends to favor focusing on the actual text of the Constitution. If you're a liberal, you're going to agree with the liberal position, which tends to focus on fairness and empathy and things like that. Republican presidents will tend to nominate conservative judges, while Democratic presidents will tend to nominate liberal judges. It is what it is. Pretty much no matter what the judges decide in a case like this, one side or the other will be outraged and the other will be elated. That's a big part of the reason why winning presidential elections is so important because it lets the president (especially if he has the Senate on his side as well) nominate judges that are likely to rule the way the president favors for decades. In this case, I think that if the healthcare law is struck down, I don't think there will be too many negative consequences for the court because the law is so unpopular. If everybody loved it, that would be different.
The care of his suffering beloved and her manifesting degeneration must have become overwhelming for Mr. Snelling and as a result he went overboard.

I was thinking the same thing. I also would guess that they had discussions about options in her earlier, lucid moments. It's entirely possible that they agreed he would take care of her so long as she was able to remain in his care.

Of course, unless / until more details are known, we can only speculate. But most people these days are aware of what an Alzheimer's diagnosis means, and I find it hard to believe that they did not discuss where they wanted their own personal lines to be drawn. It's entirely possible that this is exactly what both of them wanted and agreed upon.
My guess?  He was diagnosed with a terminal illness, had no idea who would care for him or his wife, so decided to speed the process along.  Very sad circumstances.

I read Mr. Snelling's essay, published only a few months ago, and it struck me as relentlessly upbeat and as one reader commented at the time "self-congratulory." In retrospect, he seemed to be trying to convince himself that everything was okay, when it wasn't okay. I have been volunteering in a senior care program for some time now, where we've had plenty of Alzheimer's sufferers. The fact is that it's not okay, it's hard as hell, especially on the primary caretaker, which is often an elderly spouse. The emotional and physical toll on the caretaker has now been well-documented (including as reported in the article linked below). It feels like Mr. Snelling's attempts to be upbeat about it all finally broke down in the face of reality. I wonder if the persistent attempts at having a positive mental attitude kept him from seeking the help he needed both for himself and his wife. People in this situation should get help, including caretaker support groups, rather than take it all on themselves and pretend it's not as hard as it really is.

http://jama.ama-assn.org/content/282/23/2215.full?sid=8133f86e-c102-4846...

Over 13 years, my mother cared for both of her parents with Alzheimers, first her father and then her mother. Their journey took them from their own home, to assisted living, to a string of nursing homes. I know it was so hard for my mom to do it, but I also know that her visits with her parents and the love they had for her and the appreciation they had for the care she gave brought her deep joy and fulfillment.  Genetics being what they are, I know that my siblings and I will very likely need to care for our mother in a similar way some day not too far down the road. If someone were to deny me those moments with my mother out of selfishness like this man did, I would never forgive him.  I find this horrifying.

Yes, a lovely ending, I think.  His wife no longer enjoyed her life and he knew he would not enjoy his without her.  What cold be more romantic?  I am very surprised that so many readers find it sad or wrong.  That Mr. Snelling cherished their love more than his life is beautiful and uplifting.

I don't think he should be so cruel to take someone's life, even if it's his wife and she's seriously ill. He shouldn't commit suicide either. It's cowardice not courage. He can't face the reality to live through the inevitable ending, solitude, loneliness, etc.. Simply not brave enough to face life's hard reality: nobody is saved by human love to the end.
